imageObj.caption: Image of Practice's offices in New York City

children.text: For the most part, Practice doesn’t work on Fridays. Or we do, but we’re not working for our clients. Friday is our “Dev(elopment) Day: a time set aside for internal projects, self improvement, and our various passions. After completing a couple internal initiatives, Michelle pitched the team on donating Dev Day to a good cause – supporting the community-focused anti-racist organizing of Outer Work.

The murder of George Floyd by the Minneapolis Police Department set off a blaze of interest in anti-racism work across the country. That interest was hot, bright, and brief - the urgency of the issue, especially the way it was discussed online, left even passionate advocates feeling burned out. Lenea Sims, who founded Outer Work as a passion project to build community in the wake of the murder, saw this first hand. Attendance was dropping off and engagement was waning, but the issues hadn’t gone anywhere. Something needed to change.

modules.headline: Why did the project take shape as a printed and distributed newspaper?
modules.label: Question

children.text:
We met Lenea when she was facing this crossroads, and found her vision of social change so compelling we decided to dedicate our Dev Days to helping her move forward. To beat burnout, we needed a mission that would inspire a sustainable commitment to community care. So we put our heads together and ideated around a way forward, with a focus on rooting anti-racism work in joy rather than outrage or obligation.

With that principle in mind, we started working on a new direction for Outer Work. Drawing on the idea of the work being “rooted” we started to think about the organization in the context of a community garden, a place where people come together to combine their strengths and grow something beautiful and new. Working from that vision, we decided that more than a pure brand exercise, Outer Work needed a way to physically touch people’s lives. We also wanted to get it into as many hands as possible, which meant finding the most cost-effective option. Together, those considerations led us to the newspaper.
We intentionally set the newspaper in type created by Black designers to highlight the work done by individuals like Tré Seals and Joshua Darden.

imageModules.caption: Press check at Linco Printing in Long Island City

modules.headline: How can we make hard work like anti-racism sustainable? Or even: joyful?
modules.label: Challenge

children.text: We built the paper’s editorial identity across a few months of Fridays, working to instill the Outer Work ethos in everything we did. First and foremost, that meant highlighting the work and voices of BIPOC. The type used throughout was created by Black designers, and the paper’s content was written by Lenea or members of the Outer Work community.

The community garden metaphor inspired our palette, centered on a rich brown to represent the fertile soil in which the seeds of change must be planted. A secondary palette of pastel tones standing in for green grass, the blue sky, a yellow sun, and joyful pink & lavender flowers highlights the beauty inherent in this vision.

We also infused the entire document with a spirit of interaction and play. Illustrative scribbles and scratches appear throughout the paper, encouraging the reader to engage with the text, highlighting meaningful passages or annotating it with thoughts and feelings. The back cover features lighthearted illustrations that represent and work to normalize some of the difficult feelings that show up in social change work. And the Outer Work logo itself features an organically drawn O and W that, when stacked together, create a flower. This device reinforces both the central garden metaphor and the inherent beauty of growth and change.

After we put the paper to bed, we still had to get it in people’s hands. Here too we leaned on community. Printing was handled by Linco, a smaller local business, and Practice covered all the costs. Then we worked with Lenea to coordinate a group of volunteers who handed out papers in their home cities. The street team dropped copies at bookstores, libraries, and cafes from coast to coast. One location we’re particularly happy this message will be heard? Minneapolis, Minnesota.

modules.quote: "Activism is merely one piece of a sustainable community care practice. If you aren't balancing action with consistent learning and reflection, you're setting yourself up for burnout, apathy, and a lack of fulfillment from your community work."
modules.title: Lenea Sims, Founder of Outer Work

children.text: Throughout our partnership with Outer Work, we’ve tried to embody Lenea’s approach to social change. Looking back on the journey we’ve shared, from initial ideation through donated time and covering printing costs, we’re prepared to call it a success. This is what it looks like for our studio to practice community care.

imageObj.caption: Outer Work print materials ready for delivery

modules.headline: Frankly, the idea that individuals can change the world by buying the right thing is fundamentally unrealistic and places an unfair burden on the individual.
modules.label: The problem

children.text: The business you buy your packaged goods from is the one responsible for creating the product, choosing the packaging, designing the label, and everything else. It should be their responsibility to figure out how to dispose of it all in a sustainable, responsible way.

Real change has to happen on the institutional level, but the power players have a vested interest in making individuals feel responsible for their environmental impact. After all, if we’re busy beating ourselves up over buying single use plastic or not being able to afford an electric car, we aren’t agitating for a better, more sustainable society.

modules.headline: Waste Not is part of our work to encourage brands to take ownership of their impact on the planet.

children.text: At the most basic level, Waste Not is a website. More specifically, it’s searchable database of sustainable suppliers brands can draw on as they create their products. At the highest level though, it’s an open-source template designed to be copied across industries, with the goal of making it easier for brands in any category to make sustainable choices.

modules.headline: The Waste Not website is free, straightforward, and easy to use.

children.text: It lists a variety of categories - ranging from stickers to soft goods. Within each category are products and suppliers, each of which we have run through a series of criteria that establish how effectively it reduces waste. Nothing is listed on the site unless we are confident that it is a meaningful, measurable improvement over the status quo.

modules.headline: There’s a lot of greenwashing going on, and we’re not here for it.
modules.label: Making new criteria

children.text: As a society, we’re well past the point of half measures and marginal steps — just doing better than you were before is not, in itself, sustainable. So to end up on Waste Not, a product needs to be meaningfully better than the alternatives. The vast majority of products submitted to the site are rejected on these grounds.

modules.headline: From the photography to the fonts, we worked to minimize our impact as much as possible.
modules.label: Considerations

children.text: The site itself is an effort in the direction to Waste Not. It’s built to use minimal bandwidth, with dithered images, system fonts, and as little caching and fetching of data as we could. The imagery was created for the site, but the props were painstakingly picked from a week's worth of recycling at our founder’s building - only the most aesthetic garbage, of course. The backdrops and equipment were all reused, and the fish was cooked and eaten for a post-shoot lunch.

There was no waste generated for the Waste Not project: all props were recovered from recycling or our founder Michelle Mattar’s own waste stream, which she collected for a month to get a clear picture of her own impact.

images.caption: Suitcase full of plastic packaging recovered from recycling

children.text: We photographed a sustainably hand-caught fish as a prop, and cooked it for lunch so as to not create waste.

images.caption: Suitcase full of plastic packaging recovered from recycling

imageModules.caption: Waste Not has a screensaver that goes dark to save energy

children.text: Of course we know hopping rides to a photoshoot won’t stop climate change. And we know that, at the end of the day, we can’t force people to prioritize the planet over their profit margins. But we can provide tools that let anyone start a business that takes sustainability seriously, from sourcing to shipping and everything in between.

We can make those tools available and replicable, with the hope that others will be inspired to take our code and create sibling databases for sustainability in their own industry. And we can continue to press our clients to take their impact seriously by making sustainability an explicit part of every project.

modules.headline: It’s not perfect. Even the most ethically based brands aren’t totally ethical. But we’re doing our best. We expect our clients to do their best. And we’re all working over time to do better, together.

imageModules.caption: Our first fake brand: Dirt Baby

images.caption: Dirt Baby poster reading Baby Your Plants - A just for practice project

modules.headline: What happens when a branding team develops a brand with no client, no budget, and no product?
modules.label: The idea

children.text: We’re calling it Just for Practice, an experiment to see what we can make when we remove as many constraints on our creativity as possible and apply our skills to something the whole team is equally passionate about.
Like most great ideas, Just For Practice Projects was born over coffee.

Everyone on our team regularly has ideas for new brands or businesses. These often come up during the weekly “Let’s Get Coffee” meeting we hold as a remote-friendly alternative to bumping into each other at the studio. After a few particularly exciting conversations, we decided to set aside some time to bring one of these “fake brands” to life.
We didn't produce any physical prototypes, this was Just for Practice. We designed and rendered the concept of Dirt Baby: a backpack that serves as your favorite houseplant’s home away from home.

modules.headline: How a Dirt Baby is Made
modules.label: Making the brand

children.text: The idea of doing a fake brand sprint was born during Let’s Get Coffee, and we nailed down the idea we wanted to pursue during that same unstructured time. We spent the next week’s session chatting about hypothetical companies and aligning on a shared vision of what to make. We decided to go ahead with a backpack designed to hold the wearer’s favorite houseplant, although the idea of designing a theme park for stoners also generated a lot of interest.

imageModules.caption: Some of our research for the Dirt Baby concept

children.text: With a product concept in mind, we hypothesized a target consumer and a market insight - pets are the new children, and plants are the new pets or “what if plant daddy, but too much” - and turned everything up to 11. Not only was this a fun bit of future-casting, it gave the whole team a bit of extra exposure to the strategy process. Next came a team-wide naming workshop, and Dirt Baby had its name: a play on fur baby that fit perfectly with the brand’s core “insight”.

modules.headline: We were working towards the visual identity when we found a piece of moodboarding swipe with a quieter, more emotional tone and made a snap decision to refocus the brand strategy.
modules.label: Process

children.text: And with no obligations to a client, we were free to pivot on the spot. That flexibility to experiment with our process and try new things is one of our favorite things about Practice Practicing Branding - we knew Dirt Baby wouldn’t feel right without the emotional weight of “Tiny Grass is Dreaming,” so we toned down the upbeat, playful vibe we’d been pursuing and kept moving forward. No need to sell the idea beyond the team. Just the work. This emotionally-charged framework played out perfectly in the project’s final output.

But we spent thousands of billable hours on this project. It felt important to release more than mocked up ads and packaging. Our solution was a more experiential embodiment of the brand: Dirt Baby Radio, an extensive collection of music for plants and the people who love them. We also made merch. It wasn’t the original plan, but since we’ve made a shirt for friends and family each year since we launched Practice, it made sense to celebrate Dirt Baby with the 2023 edition.
Each year at Practice, we make studio merch for friends and family. This year's edition we decided to dedicate to our first Just for Practice brand.

modules.headline: If you want to rep a business that will never exist, we’ve got shirts for sale. If you want to feel the vibe, tune into Dirt Baby Radio and grow with the flow. And if you want to hear more about what we learned developing our first Practice practice brand, read on.
modules.label: Output

children.text: Breaking down silos between disciplines is an incredible growth opportunity. We were all involved in every aspect of the project, so we all have a better understanding of writing, design, and 3D modeling than we did before. It is a great opportunity to let a designer explore strategy, or a copywriter experiment with design.

Perhaps more importantly, having deeper insight into each other’s work leads to greater empathy and better team chemistry. On client projects, we have less time to dive deeply into each other's process.
Using design and copywriting skills in a non-commercial context was really liberating. It is a joy to pursue this inherently creative work for purely creative ends.

This is not the most serious brand we’ve ever developed. Which is, of course, the point; it’s a lot easier to take risks when there’s no downside. But being brave about the choices we make in a playful context helps us build the confidence we need to take those same chances when the stakes are high. And that confidence is essential to doing great work.

offRamps.headline: Tune into our Dirt Baby Radio site of ambient music made for and by plants

zero
to existence.
We
practice
partnership

sanityFeatured.aboutBody: Founded by independent brand-builder Michelle Mattar, Practice is a creative firm that designs and builds brands from end to end.  Serving as your in-house creative team before you launch, we partner with first-time founders and established leaders alike to transform initial ideas into thriving businesses.

children.text: What
is
brand-building?

sanityFeatured.aboutPopupBody: Brand-building goes far beyond crafting a visual identity. It means creating a market-ready brand that’s grounded in strategy, designed to meet business needs, and rooted in a deep understanding of consumers and culture.
